reference.shortdesc:
The troubleshooting element is the top-level element for a troubleshooting topic. Troubleshooting topics provide information that enables readers to identify, diagnosis, and potentially remedy a problem situation.
diagnose, not diagnosis
Kris Eberlein, 08 February 2023
Thanks for catching this. I've corrected it. And changed the 2nd sentence to read "Troubleshooting topics provide information that enables readers to identify a condition, diagnose a cause, and potentially fix the problem."

section.title: Usage information
section.p: Troubleshooting topics begin with a description of a condition that the reader might want to correct, followed by one or more cause and remedy pairs. Each cause and remedy pair is a potential solution to the problem that is described in the condition. Troubleshooting topics represent the kind of information that users typically consult to fix a problem.
section.draft-comment:
Is everyone ok with "pairs" – technically, it doesn't have to be a pair. <troubleSolution> can contain one or more of <cause> and <remedy>. maybe "combinations" would be more accurate? that said, I like pairs, it's just not technically accurate.
Kris Eberlein, 12 February 2023
I went and looked at the DITA 1.3 topic. The current content of "Usage information" is the 1.3 content plus a sentence that was in an untitled section. I think it needs to be reworked to cover the DITA 2.0 changes (addition of diagnostics, making the <troubleSolution> element optional) and the more precise wording that reviewers think is needed.
I've (tentatively) changed the content of the section to read "Troubleshooting topics begin with a description of a problem that the reader might want to correct. This can be followed by diagnostic information and possible solutions to the problem."

FWIW – diagnosis precedes root cause analysis (RCA). Why are we recommending that RCA precede diagnosis? The truth is that some of the more simple troubleshooting issues can begin with an obvious RCA. Most do not.
Kris Eberlein, 10 February 2023
Is there a particular place in this topic (or collection of topics) where we recommend that root cause analysis (RCA) precedes diagnosis? An example would really help me respond to your comment.

section.title: Specialization hierarchy
section.p: The troubleshooting element is specialized from topic. It is defined in the troubleshooting module.

example.title: Example
example.p:
The following code sample contains a troubleshooting topic. The troubleshooting topic contains three cause and remedy pairs that direct the user to perform sequential troubleshooting tasks: Resetting the alarm, reseating the system memory board, and replacing the memory board. Note that some steps are reused from other topics.in this case, the word pair is accurate. there is a one to one relationship in each troubleSolution
Kris Eberlein, 12 February 2023
I've changed the second sentence to read: "The troubleshooting topic contains three troubleSolutionelements that direct the user to perform sequential troubleshooting tasks: …"
example.codeblock:
<msgph><msgnum>E247</msgnum>: Memory fault has occurred</msgph> The system has detected a memory problem.

The fault indicator flashes on the front panel, and the error log contains the E247 error message.

 p>A transient memory fault has occurred.

 Reset the alarm. Monitor the system periodically to see whether the alarm recurs.

A recurring memory fault indicates a possible problem with the system memory board. Reseating the board might fix the problem.

 p>Reseating the system memory board did not fix the problem. Replacing the board might fix the problem.
example.draft-comment:
I know that someone asked the question last time about the logic of when elements are shown in context and when they are not. My instinct on this example was to suggest adding diagnostics here and making on the solutions have a responsible party, so all elements refer to the one master example. Since most of the elements (except troubleBody) just show a portion of this example, is it necessary here? Should the extracts in the other topics be conrefs?
Kris Eberlein, 12 February 2023
I don't think we can have one troubleshooting example that we use for all elements. Reasons:
We'd have to develop an entirely new topic that included both diagnostics-general and diagnostics-steps.
The topic would be extremely long, and it would difficult for readers to locate the specific markup. It might perhaps be too long for the PDF output; if the contents of a code block covers more than a full page, our style sheets don't handle it well.
